An image loader module for nuxt.js that allows you to configure image style derivatives.
Nuxt Image Loader logo and example
This module will automatically resize, rotate, blur, watermark and crop (etc...) your images based on rules you define.
This module works by intercepting incoming image requests (on the server side) and will respond with either the source image or a
image if a query string is appended to the image URL.
Processing of images is done by defining 'image styles' in
. You can add as many of these as suits your needs.
package, so please refer the documentation there to understand the variety of image processing capabilities and options.
Works for all of nuxt deployment modes:
npm run build && npm run start
on the same host system (or container) where your application lives.
Install this module as a dependency in your project:
Your nuxt.config.js file should contain something like the following:
- This module will search a sub-directory in your nuxt application for images. By default, this is set to a sub-directory named 'content', but you can change this to the needs of your application

- This is an object containing the image processing settings where the key is the name of the image style you want to use in the image URL (see below). The value of each image style definition should contain at least one of the following key/values:
- An array of image actions to perform. For example, referring to the
you'll find several actions which can be performed. You notice for the example
example above that each action is defined with the processing method name first followed by a (
) pipe separator. If the processing method has arguments (such as height and width) then these are appended to the action delimited by further pipe separators.
- This module currently only has one macro defined called

. This does some heavy lifting to chain multiple actions together into an easy-to-read requirement. We'll add to this list of macros as we find further uses for common sets of actions. If you'd like to suggest others, please
, or, even better, submit a pull request.

In one of your nuxt pages (or layout, component etc.) create an img tag that references the image:

On refresh (or hot reload) you will see that the image has been automatically resized to 160px x 90px. If you see a smaller image than in step 2, then you've configured this module correctly. You'll also notice that a cached version of the processed image now lives in

Calling a processed image with the
component is the preferred method to load processed and original images due its clearer syntax and ability to automatically parse and generate relative URL paths which are required for
When you have this module included and loaded via your nuxt.config.js file (instructions above) you will have access to a global
component. This works very similarly to a regular
tag, except that you can supply an optional
attribute which should match once of your pre-defined image styles.
<nuxt-img src="/test.png" image-style="small" alt="Never forget alt tags!" />
Bear in mind that the root src path you supply becomes relative to your
which defaults to a directory named 'content' in the root of your application.
with dynamic data properties from your nuxt page, layout or component. For example in a Vue single file component:
You can define 'responsive image styles' to use in the module configuration. Here is an example for a 'thumb' preset:
In this example, 'thumb' is the name of the responsive style.

property is made of comma-separated definitions which closely follow the same standards as the HTML image tag specification. The difference here is that instead of referencing static image URLs as the first item of each component, you should use an existing image style definition.
In this example there are three definitions for small, medium and large. Because the browser needs to know the widths of the images
they are fetched you'll notice that the
definitions all correspond to their matching image style definition widths. You can use pixel density scaling values instead, such as
property is exactly what will be in the final HTML output as per the HTML specification for the

image attribute. These are media query style hints to the browser and you may need to trial-and-error with this to get it to work in your particular use case. You may find that you don't need it at all and instead prefer to provide CSS to perform any further size styling.
Here's an example of how you can then use 'thumb' in your
<nuxt-img src="/my-image.jpg" responsive-style="thumb" alt="Never forget alt tags!" />

This will transform to the following HTML when in static generate mode:

approach to implementing responsive images is generally easier to set up and works really well if all you want to do is improve load times on smaller devices. You may find there are limitations where art direction is concerned, e.g. when you want to swap out a landscape image for a square or portrait image as the viewport changes width. You may be able to solve this by setting appropriate image styles to match your requirements at each breakpoint and using the
attribute, although it's not been tested by the maintainer. One alternative method is to implement a

tag which may be better for you use case. This is not currently available as part of this module. If there's enough interest in getting the picture tag supported in the issue queue then this may be added as a future feature.

required for when running nuxt in
mode because lazy-loaded images send a request to the server which is intercepted by this module's serverMiddleware for on-the-fly image generation or loading an already processed image from disk.
Further advice and points of note:
Your source images should be the largest and unaltered versions you have available - or at least the maximum size you expect to use in your application.
You can organize your images files in further sub-directories if you wish. This will also be reflected in the image URL. For example, if you place a file in
or whatever style you want to apply.
You may wish to put the following into your
file so that the processed images are not committed into your version controlled files:
If you make changes to your image style settings in
the cached processed images will still exist and so you won't immediately see any change. To fix this, simply remove the cached images in the
directory or simply remove this directory altogether.
